Kent Beck wrote:

> I think my testing tool IS my design tool. When I make design decisions, I
> notate them as part of my tests. Since in my style of development I iterate
> between design, implement, and test several times a minute, I don't think
> I'd like separate tools. I use the feedback from the results of each
> activity to improve my decisions in the other activities.
> 
> What I can see clearly is the need to be able to view and manipulate the
> specification/design/tests in different ways to suit different purposes. For
> example, you can translate a test or set of tests into a sequence diagram.
> Sometimes I would like to see a summary of the design implications of my
> tests in this or some other graphical format.

Perhaps I don't want separate tools, but a way to separate the tests 
into two categories: essential and coverage. The essential tests are the 
ones that drove my design decisions, while the coverage tests are the 
ones that I added to protect against future refactorings. I think I see 
this more as a teaching technique than a practice technique, so I'll try 
thinking of it that way for a while, rather than assuming I'd want this 
in my "professional practice".

As an aside, I don't remember the mood I was one when I wrote my 
original reply, and I don't really feel that way now, so I'm left a 
little confused. Perhaps it was a case of wanting to look smart by 
saying something profound-sounding. (Kent, you really bring out the 
accountability instinct in me. I imagine that will trip me up eventually 
somehow.)

Take care.
